title: The rise of Cursor꞉ The $300M ARR AI tool that engineers can’t stop using  Michael Truell
filename: /Volumes/Extreme SSD/Downie/The rise of Cursor꞉ The $300M ARR AI tool that engineers can’t stop using  Michael Truell.mp4

paragraphs.text: Our goal with Cursor is to invent a new type of programming, a very different way to build software.

So, a world after code. I think that more and more, being an engineer will start to feel like being a logic designer. It will really be about specifying your intent for how exactly you want everything to work.
What is the most counterintuitive thing you've learned so far about building Cursor?
We definitely didn't expect to be doing any of our own model development. At this point, every magic moment in Cursor involves a custom model in some way.
What's something that you wish you knew before you got into this role?
Many companies hired too fast. I think we actually hired too slow to begin with.
You went from 0 to 100 million ARR in a year and a half, which is historic. Was there an inflection point where things just started to really take off?
The growth has been fairly consistent and exponential.
Initially, exponential growth feels fairly slow, and the numbers are low. It did not feel like it was taking off quickly.
To begin with, what do you think is the secret to your success? I think it's been...

Today, my guest is Michael Truel. Michael is co-founder and CEO of AnySphere, the company behind Cursor. If you've been living under a rock and haven't heard of Cursor, it is the leading AI code editor and is at the very forefront of changing how engineers and product teams build software. It's also one of the fastest-growing products of all time, hitting 100 million ARR just 20 months after launching and then 300 million ARR just two years since launch.

Michael has been working on AI for 10 years. He studied computer science and math at MIT, did AI research at MIT and Google, and is a student of tech and business history. As you'll soon see, Michael thinks deeply about where things are heading and what the future of building software looks like.

We chat about the origin story of Cursor, his prediction of what happens after code, his biggest counterintuitive lessons from building Cursor, where he sees things going for software engineers, and so much more. Michael does not do many podcasts. The only other podcast he's ever done is Lex Fridman, so it was a true honor to have Michael on.

If you enjoy this podcast, don't forget to subscribe and follow it in your favorite podcasting app or YouTube. Also, if you become an annual subscriber of my newsletter, you get a year free of Perplexity, Linear, Superhuman, Notion, and Granola. Check it out at lennysnewsletter.com and click "bundle." With that, I bring you Michael Truel.

This episode is brought to you by Eppo. Eppo is a next-generation A/B testing and feature management platform built by alums of Airbnb and Snowflake for modern growth teams. Companies like Twitch, Miro, ClickUp, and DraftKings rely on Eppo to power their experiments.

Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features. Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.

When I was at Airbnb, one of the things I loved most was our experimentation platform, where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own. EPPO does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, an accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying, prolonged analytic cycles.

EPPO also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel. EPPO powers experimentation across every use case, including product, growth, machine learning, monetization, and email marketing. Check out EPPO at geteppo.com/lenny and tenfold your experiment velocity. That's geteppo.com/lenny.

This episode is brought to you by Vanta. When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast. Now you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA, and more with a single platform: Vanta.

Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risk. Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI. Join thousands of global companies that use Vanta to automate evidence collection, unify risk management, and streamline security reviews.
Get 1,000 off Vanta when you go to vanta.com/lenny. That's V-A-N-T-A dot com slash lenny.
Michael, thank you so much for being here. Welcome to the podcast.
Thank you. It's great to be here. Thank you for having me.

When we were chatting earlier, you had this really interesting phrase, this idea of "what comes after code." Talk about that, just the vision you have of where you think things are going in terms of moving from code to maybe something else.

Our goal with Cursor is to invent a new type of programming, a very different way to build software. This means describing your intent to the computer in the most concise way possible. It involves defining how you think the software should work and how it should look.

With current and maturing technology, we believe we can invent a method of building software that is significantly higher-level, more productive, and in some cases, more accessible. This will be a gradual process, moving away from how software is built today.

I want to contrast this with a couple of popular visions for the future of software that we disagree with. One group believes that future software development will closely resemble today's, mostly involving text editing with formal programming languages like TypeScript, Go, C, and Rust.

Another group imagines simply typing requests into a bot, asking it to build something and then modify it. This would be a chatbot or Slackbot-style interaction, like talking to your engineering department.

We believe both of these visions have problems. Regarding the chatbot style, it lacks precision. If you want humans to have complete control over how software looks and works, you need to allow them to indicate changes in a more precise form factor than simply typing "change this about my app" into a detached text box.
Removed from the whole thing.
And then, the version of the world where nothing changes, we think, is wrong because we think the technology is going to get much, much, much better.
So, a world after code looks like one where you have a representation of your software's logic that looks more like English.
Imagine the logic of the software written down, perhaps in doctrine form, or in an evolution of a programming language towards pseudocode. You can edit this at a high level and point to it.
It will not be the impenetrable millions of lines of code. Instead, it will be something much terser, easier to understand, and easier to navigate.
That world, where the crazy, hard-to-understand symbols evolve towards something more human-readable and human-editable, is one we are working toward.
This is a profound point.

I want to make sure people understand what you are saying. You are envisioning a shift within the next year, where people will move away from even seeing or thinking in code, such as JavaScript and Python.
An abstraction will appear: pseudocode describing what the code should be doing, more in English sentences.
We think it ends up looking like that. We are very opinionated that this path goes through existing professional engineers.
It looks like an evolution away from code. It definitely looks like the human is still in the driver's seat.
The human has a ton of control over all aspects of the software and does not give that up. Also, the human has the ability to make changes very quickly, having a fast duration loop.
This means not having something in the background that is super slow and takes weeks to do all your work for you.

This begs the question for people who are currently engineers, or thinking about becoming engineers, or designers, or product managers: what skills do you think will be more and more valuable in this world of what comes after code? I think taste will be increasingly valuable.

More valuable. Often, people think about taste in software in terms of visuals, smooth animations, coloring, UI, UX, and the overall visual design. The visual side is an important part of defining software. However, as mentioned before, the other half is the logic and how the software works.

We have amazing tools for specifying visuals. When you delve into the logic of how software works, code is currently the best representation. You can gesture at it with Figma or by writing notes, but a working prototype is key.

I think being an engineer will increasingly feel like being a logic designer. It will be about specifying your intent for how everything should work, focusing more on the "what" and less on the exact "how" under the hood. Taste will become increasingly important.

We are far from this now, and there are many memes online about the trials people face when trusting AI too much for building apps with glaring deficiencies or functionality issues. But I believe we will reach a point where software engineers can be less careful. While carefulness is an incredibly important skill today, we will eventually shift from it toward taste.
This makes me think of vibe coding. Is that what you are describing when you talk about not having to think about the details as much and just going with the flow?
I think it's related. I believe that vibe coding describes exactly this controversial state of creation, where you generate a lot of code without truly understanding the details.
This approach leads to many problems. By not understanding the underlying details, you quickly reach a point where you are limited, having created something so large that it becomes unchangeable.

Some of our ideas focus on how to give people continued control over all the details, even when they don't fully understand the code. I think solutions in this area are very relevant to those who are vibe coding.

Currently, we lack the ability to allow tastemakers to have complete control over the software. A significant issue with vibe coding, despite letting taste shine through, is that much of what's created involves the AI making unwieldy decisions over which you have no control.
One more question along these lines. You threw out this word, 'taste.' When you say 'taste,' what are you thinking?
I think it is about having the right idea for what should be built.
It will become more and more about effortless translation: exactly what you want built, how you want everything to work, and how you want it to look. You will then be able to make that on a computer.

It will be less about the translation layer, where you and your team have a picture of what you want to build. This currently requires you to painstakingly lay out that vision into a format a computer can execute and interpret.
I think it is less about the UI side of things. Perhaps "taste" is a misnomer, but it is truly about having the right idea for what should be built.
I'm going to come back to these topics, but I want to zoom back out to the beginnings of Cursor. I have never heard the origin story, and I don't think many people know how this whole thing started.
You are building one of the fastest-growing products in the history of the world. It's changing the way people build products. It's changing careers, professions. It's changing so much.
How did it all begin? Were there any memorable moments along the journey of the early days?
Cursor started as a solution in search of a problem. It came from reflecting on how AI would improve over the next 10 years.

There were two defining moments. First, we were excited by using the first beta version of CodePilot. It was the first AI product we had ever used that was truly useful, not just a vaporware demo. CodePilot was also one of the most useful, if not the most useful, development tools we had ever adopted.
The second moment was the series of scaling papers from OpenAI and other places. These showed that even without new ideas, AI would improve simply by scaling up models and the data fed into them.

By late 2021 and early 2022, we were excited about the possibilities of AI products and how this technology would mature. We noticed many people discussing model creation, but few were focusing on a specific area of knowledge work and envisioning its future as AI improved.

This led us to an idea generation exercise. We asked how areas of knowledge work would change as AI technology matured, what the end state of that work would look like, and how our tools would evolve. We also considered how models would need to improve to support these changes and how scaling and pre-training would drive technological capabilities.

Our initial misstep was when we undertook a grand exercise and decided to work on an area we believed would be uncompetitive, sleepy, and boring. We thought no one would be looking at it because we felt coding was great and interchangeable with AI, but people were already pursuing that.
So, for the first four months, we worked on a very different idea: automating and augmenting mechanical engineering, building tools for mechanical engineers.

There were immediate problems. My co-founders and I were not mechanical engineers. While we had friends who were mechanical engineers, we were largely unfamiliar with the field. This created a "blind man and the elephant" problem from the outset.

We faced challenges in figuring out how to make existing models useful for mechanical engineering. We concluded that we needed to develop our own models from scratch, which proved tricky. There isn't much internet data available for 3D models of tools and parts, nor for the steps involved in their creation. Obtaining them from their sources also proved to be a difficult process.
Eventually, we came to our senses. We realized we weren't passionate about mechanical engineering; it wasn't what we wanted to dedicate our lives to.

We then looked at programming and felt that despite the time that had passed, not much had changed in that area. It seemed the people working in that space had a disconnect with our vision. They weren't sufficiently ambitious about the future direction, specifically how all software creation would flow through these models.
This realization set us on the path to building Kirsha.
That's interesting. First of all, I love that this is advice you often hear: "Go after a boring industry because no one will be there, and there's opportunity."
While sometimes that works, I love that in this journey, you actually went after the hottest, most popular space—AI, coding, app building—and it worked out.
The way you phrased it just now, you didn't see enough ambition potentially, but you thought there was more to be done. That feels like an interesting lesson.

Even if a field seems saturated, with products like GitHub Copilot and others already out there, opportunity can still exist. This is true if you notice that these products are not as ambitious as they could be, or as you are, or if you see a flaw in their approach.
Does that resonate?
That totally resonates. Part of it is the need for significant advancements—"leapfrogs"—to happen, enabling entirely new capabilities.
The exciting thing about AI, in many areas including our own, is its incredibly high potential. The ceiling is truly high.
Even if you consider the best tools available in these fields, there is still much more that needs to be done over the next few years.
This extensive space for innovation, this high ceiling, is quite unique among software areas, particularly given the degree to which AI elevates it.
Let's come back to the IDE question. There are a few routes you could have taken, and other companies are doing different routes.

One route is building an IDE for engineers to work within and adding AI magic to it. Another is a full AI agentic Devon product. A third is a model that is very good at coding, focusing on building the best possible coding model.
What made you decide that the IDE path was the best route?

The folks who were working from the start on a model or on end-to-end automation programming were trying to build something very different from us. We care about giving humans control over all the decisions in the end tool they are building. I think those folks were very much thinking of a future where, in time, the whole thing would be done by AI, and maybe the AI would be making all the decisions too.

One, there was a personal interest component. Two, I think we have always tried to be intense realists about where the technology is today. We are very, very excited about how AI will mature over the course of many decades.

However, I think there is sometimes an instinct to see AI do magical things in one area and then anthropomorphize these models, thinking it is better than a smart person here, and therefore it must be better than a smart person there. But these things have massive issues.

From the very start, our product development process was about dogfooding and using the tool intensely every day. We never wanted to ship anything that wasn't useful to us. We had the benefit of doing that because we were the end-users as part of our product.

I think that instills a realism in you about where the tech is right now. That definitely made us think that humans need to be in the driver's seat; AI cannot do everything. We were also interested in giving humans that control for personal reasons.
That approach gets you away from just being a model company. It also gets you away from this end-to-end stuff without humans having control.

The way you get to an IDE versus a plugin for an existing coding environment is the belief that programming is going to flow through these models, and the act of programming is going to change a lot over the next few years. The extensibility that existing coding environments have is so, so limited.
So, if you think the UIs may change a lot, and if you think the form factor of programs is going to change a lot, you necessarily need to have control over the entire application.
I know you guys today have an IDE, and that's probably your bias regarding where the future is heading.
But I'm curious: do you think a big part of the future will be AI engineers sitting in Slack and doing things for you? Is that something that fits into Cursor one day?

I think you will want the ability to move between all these things fairly effortlessly. Sometimes, you will want the thing to spin off on its own for a while. Then, you will want the ability to pull in the AI's work and work with it very, very quickly, and then maybe have it spin off again.

These background versus foreground form factors, I think you will want that all to work well in one place. The background stuff is especially useful for a segment of programming tasks where it is very easy to specify exactly what you want and what correctness looks like, without much description.
Bug fixes are often a great example of that, but it is definitely not all of programming. I think what IDEs will become will totally change over time.
Our approach to having our own editor was premised on it evolving over time. This evolution will include spinning off things from different surface areas, like Slack or your issue tracker.
It will also include the pane of glass you are staring at changing a lot. We mostly think of an IDE as the place where you are building software.

Something people don't talk enough about when discussing agents and how AI engineers will do work for you is this: We're all becoming engineering managers with many reports that aren't consistently smart, requiring a lot of reviewing, approving, and specifying.
What are your thoughts on that? Is there anything that could make that easier? That sounds really hard.
As anyone who has managed a large team knows, constantly receiving low-quality work from junior team members can be frustrating. It's just like, "What a life." It's going to suck.
Perhaps eventually, we'll even have one-on-one meetings with all our agents.
Many one-on-ones. The customers we've seen have the most success with AI are still fairly conservative about how they use it.

Today, the most successful customers really lean on things like our next edit prediction, where your coding is normal and we're predicting the next actions you're going to take. They also lean on scoping down the tasks you hand off to the bot.
For a fixed percentage of your time spent reviewing code, whether from an agent or an AI overall, there are generally two patterns.
One pattern is to spend a lot of time specifying things upfront. The AI then works, you review its work, and then you're done.
Alternatively, you can specify a little, let it write something, review it, specify a little more, and so on. Autocomplete falls at one end of that spectrum.
Still, we often see the most successful people using these tools are chopping things up right now and keeping things small.
That sounds less terrible. I'm glad there's a solution here.
I'm going to go back to you guys building Cursor for the first time. What was the point where you realized this was ready?
What was the moment you thought, "Okay, I think it's time to put it out there and see what happens"?
So when we started building Cursor,

We were fairly paranoid about spinning for a while without releasing to the world. To begin with, the first version of Cursor was hand-rolled. Now we use VS Code as a base, much like many browsers use Chromium as a base. However, initially, we didn't use an existing base; we built the prototype of Cursor from scratch.

That involved a lot of work. We had to build our own components. A modern code editor requires many things, including support for various languages, navigation, error tracking, an integrated command line, and the ability to use remote servers to view and run code. We quickly embarked on a blitz of building these things, creating our own editor from scratch, alongside the AI components.

After about five weeks, we were living on the editor full-time. I had discarded our previous editor and was using the new one. Once it reached a point where we found it useful, we put it in other people's hands for a very short beta period. We then launched it to the world within a couple of months from the first line of code—probably three months. It was definitely a "get this out to people and build in public quickly" approach.

What took us by surprise was that we thought we would be building for a couple of hundred people for a long time. From the get-go, there was an immediate rush of interest and a lot of feedback. That feedback was super helpful, and we learned from it. It's actually why we switched to being based off VS Code instead of our hand-rolled version. Much of that was motivated by the initial user feedback, and we've been iterating in public ever since.
I like how you understated the traction you got. You went from zero to 100 million ARR in a year, or a year and a half, which is historic.
What do you think was the key to success for something like this?
You mentioned dogfooding was a big part of it. You built it in three months; that's insane.
What do you think is the secret to your success? The first version wasn't good; the three-month version wasn't very good.
So I think it's been a sustained paranoia about all the ways this thing could get better.

The end goal is really to invent a very new form of programming that involves automating a lot of coding as we know today. No matter where we are with Cursor, it feels like we're very, very far away from that end goal.
So there's always a lot to do. I think a lot of it hasn't been over-rotated on that initial push, but instead is the continued evolution of the tool and just making the tool consistently better.
Was there an inflection point after those three months where things just started to really take off?
To me, it must have felt fairly slow to begin with. Perhaps it comes from some impatience on our part.
But I think the overall speed of the growth continues to take us by surprise.

One of the most surprising things to me is that the growth has been fairly consistent, an exponential of consistent month-over-month growth. It has been accelerated at times by our launches and other factors.
But an exponential to begin with feels fairly slow when the numbers are really low. And so it didn't really feel.
Off to the races, to begin with.
To me, this sounds like "build it and they will come" actually working. You guys built an awesome product that you loved yourselves as engineers.
You put it out, and people loved it and told everyone about it. It being all just us,
The team worked on making the product good, in lieu of other things one could spend time on.
We definitely spent time on many other things. For instance, building the team was incredibly important, and support rotations are very important.
However, we let some normal early-stage company-building activities, like sales and marketing, go unattended for a long time.
Working on the product and building something that you and your team like, then adjusting it for users, can sound simple. However, executing it well is difficult.
There were many different product directions one could have pursued. Focus, strategically picking the right things to build, and prioritizing effectively are tricky aspects.

Another tricky aspect of this domain is that it is a new, interdisciplinary form of product building. We operate somewhere between a normal software company and a foundation model company, developing a product for millions of people. That side of the business must be excellent.
An important dimension of product quality is continually advancing the science and model aspects where it makes sense. Doing that well has also been tricky.
Overall, while some of these things may sound simple to specify, executing them well is hard and consistently challenging.
I'm excited to have Andrew Luo joining us today. Andrew is CEO of OneSchema, one of our longtime podcast sponsors. Welcome, Andrew.
Thanks for having me, Lenny. Great to be here.

So, what is new with OneSchema? I know that you work with some of my favorite companies like Ramp, Vanta, and Watershed. I heard you guys launched a new data intake product that automates the hours of manual work that teams spend importing, mapping, and integrating CSV and Excel files.

Yes, we just launched the 2.0 of OneSchema FileFeeds. We've rebuilt it from the ground up with AI. We saw so many customers coming to us with teams of data engineers that struggled with the manual work required to clean messy spreadsheets.

FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV and Excel files with just a simple prompt. We support all of the trickiest file integrations: SFTP, S3, and even email.
I can tell you that if my team had to build integrations like this, how nice would it be to take this off our roadmap and instead use something like OneSchema?

Absolutely, Lenny. We've heard so many horror stories of outages from even just a single bad record in transactions, employee files, purchase orders, you name it. Debugging these issues is often like finding a needle in a haystack.

OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files. I know that importing incorrect data can cause all kinds of pain for your customers and quickly lose their trust.
Andrew, thank you so much for joining me. If you want to learn more, head on over to oneschema.co. That's oneschema.co.
What is the most counterintuitive thing you've learned so far about building Cursor and building AI products?

One counterintuitive aspect for us, as I hinted at earlier, is that we didn't expect to be doing any of our own model development when we started. As mentioned, when we began, some companies immediately focused on training models from scratch. We had calculated the cost to train GP4 and knew that wasn't something we could consistently do.

It also felt like focusing attention in the wrong area, as many amazing models already existed. Why do all this work to replicate what other players had done, especially in pre-training? That involves taking a blank neural network and teaching it the entire internet.

Consequently, we thought we wouldn't be doing that at all. It seemed clear to us from the start that existing models could do many things for us, but weren't, because the right tool hadn't been built for them.

In fact, however, we do extensive model development. Internally, it's a major focus for us in hiring, and we have assembled a fantastic team. It has also been a significant win for our product quality. At this point, every magic moment in Cursor involves a custom model.

This was definitely counterintuitive and surprising. It has been a gradual process, starting with an initial use case for training our own model where it didn't make sense to use the largest foundation models. That was incredibly successful; we then moved to another use case that worked well, and we've continued from there.

One helpful aspect of this type of model development is carefully selecting our focus areas. We avoid reinventing the wheel or focusing on areas where the best foundation models already excel. Instead, we concentrate on their weaknesses and how we can complement them.
I think this is going to be surprising to a lot of people hearing that you have your own models.
When people talk about Cursor and all the folks in the space, they would kind of call them GPT wrappers. They're just sitting on top of ChatGPT or Sonnet.
What you're saying is that you have your own models. Talk about the stack behind the scenes.
Yes, of course. We definitely use the biggest generation models in a bunch of different ways. These are really important components for bringing the Cursor experience to people.

The places where we use our own models are sometimes to serve a use case that a foundation model wouldn't be able to serve at all, often for cost or speed reasons. One example of that is the autocomplete side of things. This can be a little tricky for people who don't code to understand, but code is a unique form of work. Sometimes, the next 5, 10, 20, or even 30 minutes of your work can be entirely predicted just by looking over your shoulder.

I would contrast this with writing. Many people are familiar with Gmail's autocomplete and the different forms of autocomplete that show up when you're trying to send text messages or emails. These can only be so helpful because it's often not clear what you're going to write next just by looking at what you've written before.

However, in code, sometimes when you edit one part of a codebase, it's clear that you'll also need to change things in other parts of that codebase. One core part of Cursor is this highly suitable autocomplete experience where we predict the next set of actions you'll take across multiple files and multiple places within a file.

Making models good at that use case involves several factors. First, there's a speed component; these models need to be incredibly fast, providing a completion within 300 milliseconds. There's also a cost component because we run tons of models with every keystroke, constantly updating our prediction for what you'll do next.

We also have a highly specialized use case: models exceptionally skilled not just at completing the next token in a generic text sequence, but at auto-completing a series of diffs. This involves analyzing changes within a codebase and accurately predicting the next set of modifications, including both deletions and additions.

We have found significant success in training models specifically for this task. In this area, no foundation models are involved; it's our proprietary solution. While not heavily branded within the app, this technology powers a very core part of Cursor.

Another way we use our models is to augment tools like Sonnet, Gemini, or GPT. Our models operate both on the input and output sides of these large models. On the input side, our models search throughout a codebase to identify the relevant parts to show to one of these large models.
You can think of this as a mini-Google search specifically designed to find the pertinent sections of a codebase for these large models.
On the output side, we take the high-level sketches of changes that these larger models suggest for the codebase. Then, our models fill in the specific details.

The initial high-level thinking is performed by the smartest models, which spend only a few tokens on this task. Subsequently, smaller, incredibly fast specialty models, combined with inference tricks, transform these high-level changes into actual full-code diffs.

This approach has been incredibly helpful for enhancing quality in situations requiring a specialty task. It has also significantly improved speed, which is a crucial aspect of product quality for us.
This is so interesting.
I just had Kevin Weill, CPO of OpenAI, on the podcast, and he calls this the "ensemble of models." That's the same way they work: to use the best features of each one.
And to your point, there are cost advantages to using cheaper models.
Are these other models based on open-source models, such as Llama, that you plug into and build on?
We try to be very pragmatic about where we do this work, and we don't want to reinvent the wheel.
We start with the best pre-trained models available, often open-source ones. Sometimes, this involves collaborating with large model providers who do not share their weights publicly.
We are less concerned with the ability to read the line-by-line matrix of weights that yields a certain output. Instead, we focus on the ability to train and post-train these models.
By and large, we use open-source models, but we also work with closed-source providers to train them.
This leads to a discussion that a lot of AI founders and investors always think about: moats and defensibility in AI. It feels like custom models are a moat in this space.
How do you think about long-term defensibility in this space, knowing there are other folks, as you said, constantly launching and trying to eat your lunch?

I think there are ways to build in inertia and traditional moats. However, by and large, we are in a space where it is incumbent upon us and everyone in this industry to continue building the best product. I truly believe the ceiling is so high that no matter what entrenchment you build, you can be leapfrogged.

This resembles markets that are perhaps a little different from normal software markets or enterprise markets of the past. One example that comes to mind is the market for search engines at the end of the 1990s and beginning of the 2000s. Another market that resembles this in many ways is the development of personal computers and mini-computers in the 1970s, 80s, and 90s.

In each of those markets, the ceiling was incredibly high, and it was possible to switch. You could continue getting value for the incremental hour of a smart person’s time or the incremental R&D dollar for a really long time. You wouldn't run out of useful things to build.

In search, in particular, having distribution was helpful for making the product better. You could tune the algorithms and the learning based on the data and feedback you received from users. All of those dynamics exist in our market as well.

Perhaps the sad truth for people like us, but the amazing truth for the world, is that many more leapfrogs exist. There are many more useful things to build. We are a long way from where we can be in five or ten years, and it is incumbent upon us to keep that engine going.
What I'm hearing, this sounds more like a consumer moat. Here, you have to be the best consistently so people stick with you.
This is different from creating lock-in, like Salesforce, where contracts with the entire company mean you have to use their product.
The important thing to note is if you are in a space where you run out of useful things to do very quickly, that is not a great situation to be in.

However, if you are in a place where big investments and having more great people working on the right path can keep giving you value, then you can get these economies of scale in R&D. This allows you to work deeply on the technology in the right direction and reach a defensible position.
Yes, there is a consumer-like tendency to it. Ultimately, I think it is just about building the best thing possible.
Do you think in the future there's one winner in this space, or do you think it's going to be a world of a number of products like this?

I think the market is very big. You asked about the IDE earlier, and one thing I think some people who were thinking about the space missed is that they looked at the IDE market of the past ten years. They saw a super fragmented space where everyone had their own thing with their own configuration.

They wondered who was making money off editors. There was only one company commercially making money from great editors, but it was only so big. The conclusion was that the future would look the same.

However, I believe what people missed was that there was only so much you could do building an editor for coders in the 2010s. The company that made money off editors focused on features like easy code navigation, error checking, type checking, and good debugging tools. While these were useful, I think the range of things you can build for programmers, and knowledge workers in many different areas, goes much further and deeper.
The real problem before us is automating much of the busy work and knowledge work. We need to transform all areas of knowledge work to be much more scalable and productive.

In a long-winded way, I'm saying I think the market we're in is truly enormous. It's much bigger than people have realized, especially compared to those building tools for developers in the past. I believe there will be many different solutions.
One company will build the general tool that builds almost all the world's software. It remains to be seen if that will be us, but I believe it will happen.

This will be a very generationally big business. However, there will also be niches you can occupy by doing something for a particular market segment or a specific part of the software development lifecycle.

General programming will shift from writing formal languages to a much higher level, where you purchase and use an application for that purpose. I believe there will generally be one winner in this space, and it will be a very big business.
It's interesting that Microsoft was right at the center of this, first with an amazing product and amazing distribution.
Copilot, you said, was the thing that got you over the hump, making you realize, "Wow, there could be something really big here."
But it doesn't feel like they're winning. It feels like they're falling behind. What do you think happened there?
There are specific historical reasons why Copilot might not have lived up to the expectations that some people have for it. Then there are structural reasons.
The structural reason is this: To be clear, Microsoft, in the Copilot case, is a big inspiration for our work. In general, they do lots of awesome things, and we are users of many Microsoft products.

However, this is a market that is not super friendly to incumbents. A market that is friendly to incumbents might be one where there is only so much to do, it gets commoditized fairly quickly, and you can bundle it with other products.
The ROI between different products is quite small. In that case, perhaps it does not make sense to buy the innovative solution; it makes sense to just buy the bundled product.
Another market particularly helpful for incumbents is one where, from the outset, you have your stuff in one place, and it is excruciatingly hard to switch.

For better or worse, in our case, you can try out different tools and decide which product is better. So that is not super friendly to incumbents; it is more friendly to whoever has the most innovative product.

The specific historical reasons, as I understand them, are that the group of people who worked on the first version of Copilot have largely moved on to other things at other places. It has been difficult to coordinate among all the different departments and parties involved.
In making something like this, I want to come back to Cursor.

I like to ask everyone building a tool like this a question. If you could sit next to every new user who uses Cursor for the first time and whisper a couple of tips in their ear, what would be one or two pieces of advice for them to be most successful with Cursor?
I think right now—and we'd want to fix this at a...

At the product level, being successful with Kercher involves having a taste for what the models can do. This includes understanding the complexity of tasks they can handle and how much you need to specify things to the model. You need to develop a feel for the model's quality, its gaps, and what it can and cannot do.

Currently, we don't do a good job in the product of educating people around that, or providing guidelines. To develop that taste, we offer two tips. First, as mentioned, we would bias less toward trying to tell the model exactly what you want in one go, then seeing the output and either being disappointed or accepting the entire thing for a big task.

Instead, I would chop things up into smaller bits. You can spend basically the same amount of time specifying things overall, but in smaller chunks. You specify a little, get a little work, specify a little, get a little work. Avoid writing one giant thing telling the model exactly what to do; that will be a recipe for disaster right now. So, bias toward chopping things up.

At the same time, and it might make sense to do this on a side project rather than your professional work, I would encourage people, especially developers used to existing software workflows, to explicitly try to fall on their face. Try to discover the limits of what these models can do by being ambitious in a safe environment, like a side project, and trying to use AI to the fullest.
Often, we run into people who haven't given AI a fair shake yet and are underestimating its abilities.
Generally, we bias towards chopping things up and making them smaller. However, to discover the limits of what you can do, explicitly try to go for broke in a safe environment and get a taste for it.
You might be surprised in some of the places where the model doesn't break.
What I'm essentially hearing is...
Build a gut feeling of what the model can do and how far it can take an idea versus guiding it along.
I bet that you need to rebuild this gut every time there is a new model launch, like when, say, 4.0 comes out. You have to do this again.
Is that generally right? Yes.
For the past few years, it hasn't been as significant as the initial experience people had with some of these big models.
This is also a problem we hope to solve much better for users, taking the burden off them.
Each of these things has slightly different quirks.
and different personalities.
A common debate revolves around tools like Cursor. Are they more helpful to junior engineers, or do they benefit senior engineers more?
Do these tools make senior engineers 10x better, or do they enable junior engineers to perform more like senior engineers?
Who do you think benefits most from Cursor today?
I think across the board, both of these cohorts benefit in big ways. It is a little hard to say on the relative ranking. I will say they fall into different anti-patterns.

Junior engineers, for instance, often go a little too wholesale, relying on AI for everything. We are not yet in a place where you can do that end-to-end on a professional tool, especially when working with tens or hundreds of other people within a long-lived codebase.
Conversely, for many senior engineers, the opposite is true. They tend to underrate what AI can do for them and stick to their existing workflows. However, this is not universally true.

One way these tools are adopted is through developer experience teams within companies, often led by incredibly senior people. These individuals build tools to make other engineers more productive. We have seen some very boundary-pushing efforts here, with people on the front lines truly trying to adopt the technology as much as possible.
So, the relative ranking remains difficult. While both cohorts exhibit different anti-patterns, they both, by and large, gain significant benefits from these tools.
That makes absolute sense. I love that it's two ends of the spectrum: expecting too much or not enough. It's like The Three Bears. Is that the allegory?
Maybe the sort of senior but not staff, right in the middle.
Interesting. Okay, just a couple more questions. What's something that you wish you knew before you got into this role?
If you could go back to Michael at the beginning of Cursor, which was not that long ago, and give him some advice, what would you tell him?

The thing with this is that much of the hard-won knowledge feels tacit and difficult to communicate verbally. For some areas of human endeavor, you need to either fall on your face to learn the correct thing or be around someone who exemplifies excellence in that field.

One area where we have felt this is hiring. We tried to be incredibly patient on the hiring front because having a world-class group of engineers and researchers to work on Cursor was important for personal reasons and the company's strategy.

We looked for people who fit a mix of intellectual curiosity and experimentation, as there are many new things we need to build. Additionally, intellectual honesty, micro-pessimism, and bluntness were important qualities. With all the noise, especially as the company and business have grown, keeping a level head is crucial.
Getting the right group of people into the company, perhaps more than building the product, was something we really fussed over. We waited a long time to grow the team because of this.

Many people hear about hiring too fast; I think we actually hired too slowly to begin with. We could have remedied it and have since gotten better. The recruiting method we eventually adopted, which worked well for us, involved going after people we considered world-class and recruiting them over several years in some cases.

This method ultimately worked, but I don't think we were very good at it initially. We learned hard lessons about the right profile, who would fit on the team, what greatness looked like, and how to discuss the opportunity with someone and get them excited, even if they weren't actively looking. There were many learnings there.
About how to do that well, and that took us a bit of time. What are some of those learnings for folks who are hiring right now? What is something you missed or learned?

I think to start with, we actually biased a little bit too much towards looking for people who fit the archetype of well-known schools, who were very young, and who had done the things that were high credential in those well-known school environments. We were lucky early on to find fantastic people who were willing to do this with us, who were later in their careers.

I think we spent a bunch of time on maybe a little bit of the wrong profile to begin with. Part of that was a seniority thing; part of that was an interest and experience thing. We have hired excellent, excellent, excellent, and very young people, but they sometimes look slightly different from being straight out of central casting.

Another lesson is that we very much evolved our interview loop. Now we have a hand-rolled set of interview questions. Core to how we interview is actually having people on-site for two days to do a work test project with us. That has worked really well, and we are increasingly refining it.

I think we've gotten better over time at learning what people are interested in and putting our best foot forward to let them know about opportunities when they're not really looking for anything, and having those conversations.

This two-day work test, which we thought would not scale past a few people, has had surprising staying power. The great thing about it is it lets someone go end-to-end on a real project. It's not a "where do we use?" it's a "candlestick" project, but it gives you two days of seeing a real work product.

It doesn't have to be incredibly time-intensive for the team's time. You can take the time you would spend in a half-day or one-day onsite and spread it out over those two days, giving someone a lot of time to work on their projects. That can actually help it scale.

It really helps you enforce the "do you want to be around this person" type test because you are around this person for a few days, including a bunch of meals with them. We didn't expect that one to stick around, but it has been very important to our value-added process.

It was also important for getting people excited, especially at the very early stages of the company. Before people use the product and know about it, and when the product is comparatively not very good, the only thing you have going for you is a team of people that some people find special and want to be around.

The two days would give us a chance to have this person meet us and, in some cases, hopefully get convinced that they want to throw in with us. That one was unexpected, not exactly an interview question, but a form of an interview.
The ultimate interview question.
Just to be very clear about what you are describing: you give them an assignment, like building this feature in our actual codebase, working with the team to code it, and shipping it.
Is that roughly right? Yes.
We don't use the IP; it's not shipped end-to-end. Instead, it's like a mock project.
Very often in our codebase, we offer a real mini two-day project. You're going to do it end-to-end, largely being left alone.
There's collaboration too. We are a pretty important company, so in almost all cases, you'd actually be sitting in the office with us too.
You've mentioned that this has scaled significantly. How large is your team at this point?
We are approaching 60 people.
That's small for the scale and impact. I thought it would be a lot larger than that.
I imagine the largest percentage of your team is engineers.

More than anything, a significant part of the work ahead of us involves building a larger, more capable team that can continue to improve both the product and our customer service. We don't plan to stay this small for long, and we wouldn't hope to.
However, the reason that number is currently small is due to the high percentage of engineers, researchers, and designers within the company.

Many software companies with roughly 40 engineers would typically have over 100 people because of the extensive operational work involved. Often, they are very sales-led from the outset, which is quite labor-intensive.
In contrast, we started by being incredibly lean and product-led. We now serve many customers and build their applications, but there is still much more to do.
A question I wanted to ask you. There's so much happening in AI. There are things launching. There are newsletters, many whose entire function is to tell you what is happening in AI every single day.

Running a company at the center, kind of the white-hot center of the space, how do you stay focused? How do you help your team stay focused and heads down, to just build and not get distracted by all these shiny things?
I think hiring is a big part of it.

If you hire people with the right attitude, and all of this should be abstract, I think we're doing well there. We could probably be doing better there too, and it's something we should talk about even more as a company.

Hiring people with the right disposition—people who are less focused on external validation, more focused on building something truly great and doing high-quality work, and people who are generally level-headed where the highs aren't very high and the lows aren't very low—can get you through a lot.

This is a learning throughout the company: you need process, you need hierarchy, and you need many things. But for any organizational tool you introduce, you can go pretty far by hiring people with the behaviors you want to result from that organizational tool.

A specific example is that we've been able to get away with not a ton of process on the engineering front yet. I think we need a little more, but for our size, it's not a lot of process because we've hired people who I think are truly excellent.
One factor is hiring level-headed people. Two is just talking about it a lot. Three is hopefully leading by example.
For us personally, we've been professionally working on this and on AI since 2021 and 2022. We've seen a sea change in the comings and goings of various technologies and ideas.

If you transport yourself back to the end of 2021 or the beginning of 2022, there was GPT-3, but InstructGPT didn't exist. There was no DALL-E, no Stable Diffusion. Then we've gone through all those image technologies existing, the rise of ChatGPT, and GPT-4, all these new models, all these different modalities, and all the video stuff.
Only a very small number of these things really affect the business. So I think we've built up an immune system and know when an event comes around that truly matters for us.
This dynamic, where there's lots of chatter but only a few things truly matter, has been mirrored in AI over the last decade. There have been so many papers on deep learning and AI in academia.

The amazing thing is that much of AI's progress can be attributed to some very simple, elegant ideas that have endured. The vast majority of ideas put out there haven't had staying power or mattered significantly.
This dynamic is mirrored in the evolution of deep learning as a field.
Last question. What do you think people still most misunderstand or perhaps don't fully grasp about where things are heading with AI in building, and how the world will change?

People are still a little bit occupied too much at either end of a spectrum. Either it's all going to happen very fast, or this is all bluster and snake oil. I think we're in the middle of a technology shift that's going to be incredibly consequential. I think it's going to be more consequential than the internet and any shift in tech we've seen since the advent of computers.

I think it's going to take a while; it will be a multi-decade thing. Many different groups will be consequential in pushing it forward. To get to a world where computers can increasingly do more for us, all these independent problems need to be knocked down, and progress needs to be made on them.

Some of those problems are on the science side of things: getting these models to understand different types of data, be faster, cheaper, smarter, conform to the modalities we care about, and take actions in the real world. Others relate to how we will work with them and what experience a human should actually see and control on a computer when working with these things.

I think it's going to take decades, and there will be lots of amazing work to do. A particularly important group, not to talk our own book, will be companies that automate and augment a specific area of knowledge work.

This involves building the underlying technology, integrating the best parts from providers—sometimes in-house—and also building the product experience. People who do this, whether in software or other areas, will be very consequential.

This is not just for the end value users see. As they scale, they will be very important for pushing forward the technology, as the most successful among them will be able to build very large businesses. I'm excited to see the rise of other companies like that in other areas.
I know you guys are hiring. For folks interested in working here and building this sort of stuff, what kind of roles are you looking for right now?
Are there any specific roles you're most excited about filling ASAP?
What should people know if they're curious?

There are many things this group needs to do that we are not yet equipped for. If you don't think we have a role for something, please reach out; that might not be the case. We might even learn from you and realize we need something we weren't aware of.
By and large, two of our most important goals this year are to have the best product in the space and to grow it.
We are in a land grab mode where almost everyone in the world is either using no tool like ours or one that is developing less quickly. Growing Curriculum Studio is a big goal.
We are always on the hunt for excellent engineers, designers, and researchers, and we are focusing on business-side roles as well.
I can't help but ask this question now that you're talking about engineers. There's this idea that AI will write all our code, but everyone's still hiring engineers like crazy.

Many foundational model companies are hiring a lot, and it doesn't seem like they're trying to cheat the market. Do you think there will be an inflection point where engineering roles start to slow down?
I know this is a big question, but do you see engineers being more and more needed across all these companies? Or do you think at some point, there will be agents running and building for us?

We have the view that there's a long, messy middle where things won't immediately jump to a state where you just step back, ask for all your stuff to be done, and your engineering department handles it. We want to evolve from programming as it exists today, keeping humans in the driver's seat. Even in the end state, giving people control over everything is crucial.
You will still need professionals to decide what the software looks like. Therefore, engineers are definitely needed and will be able to accomplish much more. The demand for software is very lasting.

It's astonishing how expensive and labor-intensive it is to build things that are relatively simple and easy to specify, at least to an outside observer. These tasks are incredibly difficult to execute right now. If you could reduce the cost and demand that currently justifies all existing software by orders of magnitude, we would have an immense amount of additional things we could do on computers and many more tools.

I've experienced this firsthand. One of my early jobs involved building internal tools for a biotechnology company. The off-the-shelf tools were terrible and didn't fit their use case at all. There was a huge demand for the internal tools I was building, far exceeding what I could accomplish in the time I was with them.

The physics of working on computers are still so great; you should basically be able to move everything around and do everything you want to do. However, there's still so much friction. There's much more demand for software than what we can build today, with some simple productivity software costing as much as a blockbuster movie to create. Therefore, I believe that long into the future, yes, there will actually be a need for engineers.
More demand for engineers.
Is there anything we didn't cover that you wanted to mention, any last negative wisdom you wanted to leave listeners with?
You could also say no, because we've done a lot.

We think a lot about how to set up a team to make new things while also improving existing ones. For us to be successful, our core idea will need to change significantly. What it looks like will also need to evolve considerably in the future.

If you look at the companies we respect, there are certainly examples of those that have consistently ridden waves of innovation, making many leapfrogs and pushing the frontier. However, such companies are rare. It is a difficult feat to achieve.

Therefore, part of our approach involves consistently reflecting on this challenge in our daily work and from a first-principles perspective. Additionally, we study past examples of greatness in this area.

That's something we think about a lot, too. Before we started recording, you had all these books behind you. I asked what that was, and you mentioned it was the history of an old, influential computer company I'd never heard of. I think that says a lot about you, as much innovation comes from studying the past, history, and understanding what has worked and what hasn't.
Where can people find you online if they want to reach out or apply? You mentioned there might be roles they aren't even aware of; where can they find those? How can listeners be useful to you?
If you are interested in working on this, I would love to speak with you.
You can find our product and learn how to reach us by visiting curse.com.
Michael, thank you so much for being here. This was incredible. It was wonderful. Thank you. Bye everyone.
Thank you so much for listening. If you found this valuable, you can subscribe to the show on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or your favorite podcast app.
Also, please consider giving us a rating or leaving a review, as that really helps other listeners find the podcast.
You can find all past episodes or learn more about the show at lennyspodcast.com.
See you in the next episode.
